solution_line_template: The two t-shirts amount to ${tshirt_cost_per_piece} x {num_tshirts} = $<<{tshirt_cost_per_piece}*{num_tshirts}={cost_tshirts}>>{cost_tshirts}.
The two bags amount to ${bag_cost_per_piece} x {num_bags}= $<<{bag_cost_per_piece}*{num_bags}={cost_bags}>>{cost_bags}.
So Timothy spent ${cost_tshirts} + ${cost_bags} = $<<{cost_tshirts}+{cost_bags}={total_spent_shirts_bags}>>{total_spent_shirts_bags} for the shirts and bags.
He still has ${initial_money} - ${total_spent_shirts_bags} = $<<{initial_money}-{total_spent_shirts_bags}={money_left}>>{money_left} left to spend for the key chains.
With the money, he can buy ${money_left}/${keychain_set_cost} = <<{money_left}/{keychain_set_cost}={num_keychain_sets}>>{num_keychain_sets} sets of key chains.
Therefore, he can buy {num_keychain_sets} x {pieces_per_keychain_set} = <<{num_keychain_sets}*{pieces_per_keychain_set}={total_keychain_pieces}>>{total_keychain_pieces} pieces of key chains.
